Posts.Content: Oct 19, 2007 05:53AM ophelia wrote: Hi mamhop, I've been reading your posts and I know how stressed and worried you have been.  That's wonderful news. I couldn't be happier for you.  I know you still have the other side to contend with and I know you have been struggling with choices and decisions.  I hope this good news brings you some comfort.   Be confident in you're decision making.  Only you will know what is right for you.  Trust your gut and once you've decided don't look back.  I've been struggling with PBM for sometime and I have finally reached a decision.  Its been hard but I know its the only thing that will bring me peace. I will continue to keep you in my prayers. Sending you many hugs....

Posts.Title: Stage 3 or 4. How many still here 5 yrs later? tooyoungtohavebc SpunkyGirl

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2008 07:49PM ophelia wrote: Prycylla, I understand your anger. I have been there with my mom.  She hid a lump for 5 years because she was afraid and in denial. When she finally said something it had progressed to stage IV and had made out to 4 lymph nodes.  Her tumor was so large that the bs said they would not be able to do surgery unless it shrunk.   She started chemo and the tumor shrunk considerably. She had a unilat masc. but he didn't feel she'd have more than 1 to 2 yrs.  That was 5 1/2 years ago.  We just celebrated her 75 birthday on the 14th, and she is doing very well. Your mom is scared and probably in denial as mine was.  If so, she'll need you to be strong and let her know she can count on you to help her through this.  It doesn't have to be a death sentence if she allows herself to get treated.  Please share the information that you have found here with her.  God bless you and your mom.
Posts.Title: how to deal with anger prycylla althea

Hang in there... better days are coming.

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2008 06:11PM ophelia wrote: Hi nowwhat, I finally called my dr and she told me that she believes its cording. I can actually feel this cording in my armpit.  She told me to try the wall crawl 3 times per day, followed by warm compresses, and then massaging the area.  I've been doing this and it seems to help right after I've done it but then it seems to return.  I do have a prescr. for therapy which I'll probably have to start soon.  I was hoping to avoid it. Good luck to you.

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2008 05:38PM ophelia wrote: Usually by the time the drains are removed the fluid accumulation is minimal and can be absorbed by the body.  However, if you were to have a problem the doc. could aspirate the fluid in his office with a needle. I don't thinks thats a painful procedure.  Hope everything goes well today.  You will definetly feel better having those drains out.

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2008 08:05PM ophelia wrote: Sorry they didn't take the drains.  You'll definetly feel better once they are gone.  On the other hand its better that they stay in until they're ready to come out. Posts.Content: ophelia wrote: Hi Ladies, I'm posting for my mom.  She was diagnosed in 2003 with stage IV, IDC,HER2-.  Had Unil Mast, chemo, and rads... and has been doing fairly well.  About a week ago she started to feel pain in her hip area which she says radiates down to her knee.  I have called her onc and he has scheduled her for a bone scan on May 19th. My questions areas follows: What's involved in doing a bone scan, is it painful, does it cause anxiety for most? Also, if this turns out to be bone mets, which I'm fearing, what is the standard course for treatment and is it very painful.  My mom just turned 75, in April, and I don't know how much more treatment she can handle.   I have been lurking here for a longtime, even though I don't usually post on this thread, I get a lot of valuable information that I pass on to her.  I have immense respect for all you, as you are all very well informed and truly supportive of one another.  I include you all in my prayers, often, and will continue to pray for a cure for all of us. Be well... Maria Dx LCIS, Stage 0, 0/2 nodes Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2008 02:59PM - edited Apr 21, 2008 03:00PM by ophelia Deidre, It was wrong of that dr not to spend sometime explaining everything.  But I know from experience that we can be so overwhelmed that we don't hear some of what has been said, and forget to ask questions.  I think it would be wise to speak with this dr again and take of list of questions with you. Also if possible have your husband go with you, another set of ears is sometimes helpful.  I would want to know as much as possible about what was found and what my options are.  And if you are not satisfied with the answers you are being given, then seek out other opinions. It doesn't sound like any further action is going to be required.  But you'll be more at ease once you fully understand what is going on, and know that you have done everything you were supposed to. Be well...

I got through it but I think I must be a bit claustrophobic.  Can anyone tell me if their head was inside or out.  Are you able to see  out of the unit?  I'm trying to decide whether or not to take a happy pill.  I realize this is stupid.  I should be praying for good results and not worring about the rest.  As always thanks for your help. Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2008 11:06PM ophelia wrote: Hi Deidre, I had a similar dx 3 yrs ago.  I was told I had atypical ductal hyperplasia and bordeline DCIS.  My treatment was to be watched very carefully with mamo's and exams every six months.  I was also placed on tamoxifen.   I fully understand not knowing how to feel. It's not bad news and yet it's not exactly comforting either.  The positive is that you'll be more diligent with mamos and watched more carefully, so if something were to happen you'd be catching it early.  Have you seen an oncologist? If you are not comfortable with what you've been told you should try to schedule an appt with one. Take care...  Stay positive
